  • Method Details

    • applyMask

      public static int[] applyMask​(int[] arr, boolean[] mask)
      Creates a new array by applying a boolean mask to an input array.
      Parameters:
      arr - an array of numbers (input array)
      mask - an array of boolean values (mask array)
      Returns:
      a new array containing each element of the input array whose corresponding mask value is true, or an empty array if the two input arrays are different lengths.
      Example:
      If arr is [7,2,8,3,9,4], and mask is [1,1,0,1,0,0], then the result should be [7,2,3].

    • concatenate

      public static int[] concatenate​(int[] arrA, int[] arrB)
      Creates a new array containing all of the elements of two input arrays.
      Parameters:
      arrA - an input array
      arrB - another input array
      Returns:
      a new array containing all the elements from both arrays

    • contains

      public static boolean contains​(int[] arr, int key)
      Determines whether an array of numbers contains a certain key.
      Parameters:
      arr - an array of numbers
      key - the key to match
      Returns:
      true if the key is in the array; false otherwise

    • cumulativeSums

      public static int[] cumulativeSums​(int[] arr)
      Creates an array containing the cumulative sums of the input array.
      Parameters:
      arr - the input array
      Returns:
      a new array containing the cumulative sums
      Example:
      If arr is [7,2,8,3,6], then the result should be [7,9,17,20,26].

    • elementwiseSums

      public static int[] elementwiseSums​(int[] arrA, int[] arrB)
      Creates an array containing the element-wise sums of two input arrays.
      Parameters:
      arrA - one input array
      arrB - the second input array
      Returns:
      a new array containing the element-wise sums, or an empty array if the two input arrays are different lengths.
      Example:
      If arrA is [7,2,8,3,6], and arrB is [8,3,2,6,9], then the result should be [15,5,10,9,15].

    • frequency

      public static int frequency​(int[] arr, int key)
      Counts how many elements of an array are equal to a certain key.
      Parameters:
      arr - an array of numbers
      key - the key to match
      Returns:
      the number of matches

    • isSorted

      public static boolean isSorted​(int[] arr)
      Determines whether an array of numbers is sorted in ascending order.
      Parameters:
      arr - an array of numbers
      Returns:
      true if the array is sorted in ascending order; false otherwise.

    • merge

      public static int[] merge​(int[] arrA, int[] arrB)
      Merges two sorted arrays.
      Parameters:
      arrA - an sorted array in ascending order
      arrB - another array sorted in ascending order
      Returns:
      the array that results from merging the two arrays while preserving sorting, or an empty array if either input array is not sorted.
      Example:
      If arrA is [2,7,9,15,18], and arrB is [5,12,24,26], then the result should be [2,5,7,9,12,15,18,24,26].

    • reverse

      public static int[] reverse​(int[] arr)
      Creates a new array with the input array's elements reversed.
      Parameters:
      arr - the input array
      Returns:
      a new array with the input array's elements in reverse order

    • scale

      public static int[] scale​(int[] arr, int scalar)
      Multiplies each element of an array by a scalar.
      Parameters:
      arr - an array of numbers
      scalar - the scalar to multiply each array element by
      Returns:
      a new array of numbers such that each element is the original element multiplied by the scalar.
      Example:
      If arr is [7,2,8,3] and scalar is 5, then the result should be [35,10,40,15].
